thread.title: Pence encourages boy in fight for experimental drugs
thread.title_full: Pence encourages boy in fight for experimental drugs

author: indystar.com
title: Pence encourages boy in fight for experimental drugs

locations.name: south lawn of the white house

text:
CLOSE Skip in Skip x Embed
x Share
President Donald Trump says he wants to lower drug prices and bring pharmaceutical companies back to the United States. (Jan. 31) AP
Jordan McLinn, 7, of Indianapolis shares a high-five with Vice President Mike Pence at his ceremonial office in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building on Feb. 7, 2017. McLinn has muscular dystrophy and he and others with serious diseases are lobbying the federal government to allow them to use experimental drugs. (Photo: White House)
59 WASHINGTON – Jordan McLinn was at Mike Pence’s side when, as governor, Pence signed into law legislation to allow terminally ill patients access to experimental drugs not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
Now Vice President Pence told the 7-year-old Indianapolis boy and his mother Tuesday he wants to give Jordan the same experience at the federal level.
“He looked at me and said, `I’m looking forward to seeing you at the signing, if not sooner,’” Jordan’s mother, Laura, told reporters Wednesday.
Advocates of “Right to Try” legislation — which has been adopted in 33 states — renewed their push for a federal version this week.
They’re encouraged by comments President Donald Trump made, when meeting with pharmaceutical executives last week, about how hard it is for terminally ill patients to get new drugs.
“We’re going to be changing a lot of the rules,” Trump said.
When a boy whose father is dying of Lou Gehrig’s disease asked Pence about the issue during a campaign event in Pennsylvania last year, Pence promised a Trump administration would “open the doors to treatment.”
Great to spend time w/families working to make a difference for terminally ill patients. pic.twitter.com/hrQbbYdxBf
— Karen Pence (@SecondLady) February 8, 2017 The White House said Pence met with the McLinns and other advocates Tuesday to encourage them to keep fighting for federal legislation.
“It’s important to know that we have support from them,” McLinn said. “We want to see it go through Congress and be signed into law.”
Bills introduced in the House and Senate last year didn’t advance out of committee. Sponsors are trying again this year.
Indiana’s senators — Democrat Joe Donnelly and Republican Todd Young — have signed on to the Senate’s version . Several members of Indiana’s House delegation also have backed a change at the federal level.
FDA officials have said they’ve tried to make it easier for physicians to request access to drugs still under investigation.
But without a change in national law, advocates say doctors often aren’t comfortable given experimental drugs to terminally ill patients, even in states which have passed “Right to Try” laws.
Jordan, who has a form of muscular dystrophy, is being screened for a clinical trial for an experimental drug.
The visit to the vice president’s office was a fun distraction from dealing with his disease.
He sat at Pence’s desk and listened to the vice president tell him how the teddy bear was inspired by President Theodore Roosevelt.
It wasn’t just a one-way conversation. Jordan came prepared with a joke.
“Why did the banana put sunscreen on?” Jordan asked the vice president. “So he wouldn’t peel.”
Pence gave him a high-five.
“That’s a good joke,” Pence said.
Contact Maureen Groppe at mgroppe@gannett.com. @mgroppe.
